p: The risk of contamination and the issues with sensitivity are important to sequencing viral nucleic acids, because they cause false positive and false negative results, respectively. High-sensitivity sequencing (be it metagenomic, PCR-based or probe-enriched) allows for detection of minimal quantities of contaminating viral nucleic acids [ 208, 209]. For example, murine leukemia virus (MLV) [ 198, 210] and Parvovirus-like sequences [ 99, 211] are only two kinds of the vast range of common contaminants found even in commercial laboratory supplies [ 212].
